factoid: Arakchéev said “I don’t want one.”
Arakchéev repeated “A member without salary.”
Arakchéev shouted “Call the next one!”
Arakchéev shouted “Who else is there?”
Arakchéev bowed to Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew was waiting for the announcement of his appointment to the committee.
Prince Andrew looked up his former acquaintances.
Prince Andrew looked up former acquaintances who were in power.
Prince Andrew looked up former acquaintances whose aid he might need.
Prince Andrew experienced in Petersburg a feeling similar to the feeling he had on the eve of a battle.
Prince Andrew felt anxious curiosity in Petersburg.
Prince Andrew was irresistibly attracted to the ruling circles in Petersburg.
The ruling circles in Petersburg were shaping the future on which the fate of millions depended.
Prince Andrew felt irritation from older men in Petersburg.
Prince Andrew felt curiosity from uninitiated people in Petersburg.
Prince Andrew felt reserve from initiated people in Petersburg.
Prince Andrew felt hurry and preoccupation from everyone in Petersburg.
Prince Andrew learned about innumerable committees and commissions in Petersburg every day.
Prince Andrew believed that in 1809, in Petersburg, a vast civil conflict was being prepared.
Prince Andrew believed that the commander in chief of the civil conflict was a mysterious person he did not know.
Prince Andrew believed that the commander in chief was supposed to be a man of genius named Speránski.
Prince Andrew had a vague idea about a movement of reconstruction.
Speránski was the chief promoter of the movement of reconstruction.
The movement of reconstruction began to interest Prince Andrew so keenly that the question of army regulations receded to a secondary place in his consciousness.
Prince Andrew was favorably positioned to secure good reception in the highest and most diverse Petersburg circles of the day.
The reforming party cordially welcomed Prince Andrew.
The reforming party courted Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew was reputed to be clever.
Prince Andrew was reputed to be very well read.
Prince Andrew had liberated his serfs.
Prince Andrew obtained the reputation of being a liberal by liberating his serfs.
The party of the old and dissatisfied censured the innovations.
The party of the old and dissatisfied turned to Prince Andrew expecting his sympathy.
The party of the old and dissatisfied expected Prince Andrew's sympathy in their disapproval of the reforms.
Prince Andrew was the son of his father.
The feminine society world welcomed Prince Andrew gladly.
Prince Andrew was rich.
Prince Andrew was distinguished.
Prince Andrew was a good match.
Prince Andrew was almost a newcomer.
Prince Andrew had a halo of romance because of his supposed death and the tragic loss of his wife.
The general opinion of all who had known Prince Andrew previously was that he had greatly improved during the last five years.
Prince Andrew had softened during the last five years.
Prince Andrew had grown more manly during the last five years.
Prince Andrew had lost his former affectation during the last five years.
Prince Andrew had lost his pride during the last five years.
Prince Andrew had lost his contemptuous irony during the last five years.
Prince Andrew had acquired the serenity that comes with years.
People talked about Prince Andrew.
People were interested in Prince Andrew.
People wanted to meet Prince Andrew.
The day after his interview with Count Arakchéev, Prince Andrew spent the evening at Count Kochubéy’s.
Prince Andrew told Count Kochubéy about his interview with Síla Andréevich.
Count Kochubéy spoke of Arakchéev by the nickname Síla Andréevich.
Count Kochubéy spoke of Arakchéev with the same vague irony that Prince Andrew had noticed in the Minister of War’s anteroom.
Count Kochubéy told Prince Andrew that even in this case he cannot do without Michael Mikháylovich Speránski.
Count Kochubéy told Prince Andrew that Speránski manages everything.
Count Kochubéy told Prince Andrew that he will speak to Speránski.
Count Kochubéy told Prince Andrew that Speránski has promised to come this evening.
Prince Andrew asked what Speránski has to do with the army regulations.
Count Kochubéy shook his head smilingly.
Count Kochubéy was surprised at Bolkónski’s simplicity.
Count Kochubéy said that they had been talking to Speránski about Prince Andrew a few days ago.
Count Kochubéy said that they had been talking to Speránski about Prince Andrew's freed plowmen.
An old man of Catherine’s day said to Prince Andrew that he had freed his serfs.
The old man turned contemptuously toward Bolkónski.
Prince Andrew replied that the estate he freed was a small estate that brought in no profit.
Prince Andrew tried to extenuate his action so as not to irritate the old man uselessly.
The old man said he was afraid of being late.
The old man said there was one thing he did not understand.
The old man said he did not understand who will plow the land if the plowmen are set free.
The old man said it is easy to write laws but difficult to rule.
The old man said it is the same as now; he asked Count Kochubéy who will be heads of the departments when everybody has to pass examinations.
Count Kochubéy replied that those who pass the examinations will be heads of the departments.
Count Kochubéy crossed his legs.
Count Kochubéy glanced round.
The old man said he has Pryánichnikov serving under him.
The old man said Pryánichnikov is a splendid man.
The old man said Pryánichnikov is a priceless man.
The old man said Pryánichnikov is sixty.
The old man asked if Pryánichnikov is to go up for examination.
